notesStmt.note:
This letter, penned around June 19th, 1863, contains the information shared between husband and wife concerning the former's job as a river boat captain, the unpredictable nature of river trade, and a summation of the captain's bout with illness. The single folded sheet, yellowed with age, has writing on both the front and back in black ink, as well as a printer's mark in the upper left hand corner. Along with previous and subsequent letters, Anderson's June 19th writing helps to form a cohesive image of everyday life.
Letter of June 19th, 1863
Click here
Letter of June 19th, 1863
William B. Anderson's letter dated June 19th, 1863 from St. Louis, Missouri, is addressed to his wife Louisa and is written in ink on both sides of a loose sheet of off-white paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 9.0 inches tall (19 x 23 cm). The paper is ruled with horizontal lines of a blue color that are spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) top margin that is unruled. The sheet's left edge is not a clean line like the remaining three, suggesting that it was most likely torn from a notepad of some sort. Written in black ink, the letter appears to have originally been folded once horizontally and twice vertically. A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper left corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge of the paper and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the exact origins of the mark is inconclusive, it resembles a similarly sized and placed printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, that reads: "MT HOLLY PAPER CO."

projectDesc.p: In the words of David Levy, "no document, no genre, is an island" (29). This certainly rings true for the letters of W.B. Anderson. The transcription of Anderson's private letter to his wife serves to reveal insight into aspects of daily and personal life in the 19th century. Because Anderson exists as a model of the 19th century average man, the letter allows us to understand the unreliable nature of riverboat business, illness, medication, and the struggles of maintaining a marriage that is separated by distance - all factors that were unavoidable for many 19th century families.

The translation of his words as they appear on paper are significant indicators of the degree of education an individual such as Anderson would have experienced. Furthermore, by examining the span of time and distance between the captain's letters to his wife, we are able to better understand the scope of a career on a 19th century riverboat. Anderson frequently insisted that his wife reply to his letters soon - the infrequency of her writing is indicative of both the realities of her busy life and the unreliable nature of the early American postal system (Hewitt). Additonally, the letter allows us to have insight into the illnesses and ailments of the day, which, judging from the subject matter of the letter, were frequent and persistent realities to the life of a riverboat captain. Anderson lists several maladies that plagued him - ague, bilious fever, and neuralgia - and discusses how these complicated his daily work at length.
Hewitt, Elizabeth. Lecture to English 569C, Digital Media and English Studies. The Ohio State University. 6 Apr. 2006.
Levy, David M. Scrolling Forward: Making Sense of Documents in the Digital Age. New York: Arcade, 2001.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: My Dear Wife: A Riverboat Captain's Missive to His Love

div1.p: On June 19th, 1863, riverboat captain William B. Anderson penned a letter to his wife from St. Louis, Missouri, in which he informs his spouse of matters concerning river travel, his salary, and a bout of illness that left him bedridden.
Previous letter 16 October 1862 (Not yet edited) Next letter01 July 1863

I will commence a letter to you
this afternoon & Finish it tomorrow we arrived
here last night about Midnight we had
a fair trip around & if we get as good a one
back we will make a little money times are very
dull & and prices poor we had all the freight we could
carry on the water I have several small lots engaged
to go back to Louisville & Cin. & I think by Monday
night we shall have all we can carry I had thought
somebody would be here and offer to buy the boat but
the Boat fervor has subsided greatly I had a visit
from Capt. R. C. Gray 3 today & he says that he thinks that
the upper Mississippi river trade would pay us better
than the St Louis and Cin. trade but I dont wish to go up
there for the present. I had an offer at Cin. to sell & I will
know what I can do when I return if the party accepts my
offer I will be home Shortly.

Sunday Evening I have been rather under the weather
since I left Louisville & had today to have a
Doctor & he gave me a lot of Medacin and as
Soon as I took of it got better he says I would
have had the ague 4 or a bad attack of Billious
fever 5 if I had not had relief soon I thought
it was the Neuralgia 6 I had, for one side of
of my face & jaw pained me constantly
and my teeth ached & I had one of them
pulled and it did not do any good and
for 48 hours, I had not eaten one bite nor
slept one minute. I was not well one minute
at a time until I took the medicine and it
acted like a charm I am of course weak
but feel well and tomorrow I want to go
and see Belle Ferguson 7 I have not been out
of my room nor in fact out of bed all
day till this Evening. I would not have
believed that a few doses of medicine would
do so much in so short a time. I will
send you a paper or two tomorrow I
hope you are well give my love to
the children excuse this poor letter
for I can assure you that I have had
better to say – I will leave here for
Cin Tomorrow night without I get
disappointed. I have been unable to go
up Town to see how it looks but will
Tomorrow if nothing happens & my
health improves I feell sure I will
be all right again in a day or two

closer.signed:
WBAnderson
P.S. I will write again Tomorrow any how
WBA

div1.head: Notes
div1.note: 1. June 19th of 1863 was a Sunday, not a Saturday. This is most likely an unintended error on Anderson's part, possibly due to confusion resulting from a recent sickness that kept the river boat captain confined to his bedchamber.

2. Anderson married Mary Louisa Fischgens on September 15th, 1853 in Cincinnati, Ohio. Born on April 14th 1837 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Mary Louisa mothered five children with Anderson before her death in Pittsburgh on August 25th, 1911.History of Allegheny Countyp. 298-299
3. A business partner of Anderson's. Together they commissioned the construction of the steamer Denmark.History of Allegheny Countyp. 298

4. A fever consisting of cold, hot, and sweating stages. The name ague was initially given to the burning or feverish stage, but afterwards usually applied to the cold or shivering stage, as being the most striking external characteristic of the ailment.Oxford English Dictionary
5. This antiquated term, the correct spelling of which is "bilious," was used in the 19th century to describe the presence of increased secretions of bile.Oxford English Dictionary
6. This term refers to pain in a location resulting from a nerve.Oxford English Dictionary
7. An unidentified aquaintance of Anderson's who resided in or near St. Louis, Missouri.
